em.p: .NET Magazine: Mono is a major undertaking. What is Ximian's interest in coordinating this project, and how does Ximian earn a return on this investment?

blockquote.p: Miguel de Icaza: Remember this is an open source project, so we depend on the open source community. The Mono project at Ximian is fairly small. We have five people and one manager dedicated to the entire thing. A lot of it could come from third-party people. What you see here is what has happened with people outside Ximian contributing to the project. Fortunately for us, there are a lot of people interested in the technology who share our preferences for open source. We at Ximian are very focused on the desktop and our main interest is Windows Forms, but a lot of people are interested in ASP.NET. ASP.NET is being half done by developers outside Ximian; and ADO.NET was developed completely outside of Ximian's control, then contributed back to us.

ul.li: The ultimate goal of Portable.NET is not to generate a Return On Investment for a specific profit-oriented company, but rather to meet everyone's needs for a Free Software system that is compatible with .NET

While Portable.NET also welcomes contributions, both from volunteers and from interested companies (development sponsorships from companies are also welcome), in Portable.NET no contributor is considered "outside".

While Ximian says that they are very focused on the desktop and mainly interested in Windows Forms, these areas are important for Portable.NET also. However from the perspective of Portable.NET, embedded systems are as important as desktop systems, and webservices are as important as GUI applications.

For the sake of compatibility with .NET, Portable.NET is also working on an ASP.NET implementation. However, Portable.NET is part of the DotGNU project which is not satisfied with merely re-implementing what Microsoft has - rather it is time for Free Software to take the intitiative and gain a position of technological leadership. For example, because web browsers are a poor platform for GUIs in general, we hope that browser-based ASP.NET "web applications" will be rendered obsolete by PHP as well as an emerging Free Software technology called XWT.
